newsitem.title: GUATEMALA: Guatemala fires top army men in corruption scandal.
newsitem.headline: Guatemala fires top army men in corruption scandal.

text.p: Two generals, including a deputy defence minister, and 16 other officials were fired in an attack against corruption, the government said on Wednesday.
"This is an unprecedented purge," Nery Morales, spokesman for the interior ministry, told reporters. Those fired included police officers, three army colonels and customs officials.
The dismissals followed last weekend's arrest of Alfredo Moreno Molina, a former military intelligence officer and the suspected boss of a smuggling and robbery ring.
The police, army and customs officials arrested were all suspected of connection to Moreno's alleged criminal network.

The purge came on the eve of a historic peace treaty to be signed on Thursday in Mexico City by the government and leftist rebels, which will cut the powerful army by one third as a condition of peace at the end of Guatemala's 36-year civil war.
Guatemalan military personnel suspected of crimes have traditionally enjoyed impunity and have mostly evaded the justice system.
Chief of police Angel Conte Cojulun told reporters the attorney general's office was investigating possible criminal charges against all of the officials and will issue arrest warrants.

Col. Edgar Palacios, an army spokesman, said the dismissed army officers were all confined to military barracks and would be turned over to the justice system pending investigations and arrest warrants.
Several of the military officers rounded up in this week's corruption investigations were previously linked to prominent cases of human rights abuses.

The fired deputy defence minister, Gen. Cesar Augusto Garcia Gonzalez, had been linked to a possible cover-up related to the 1992 disappearance of guerrilla commander Efrain Bamaca, whose wife, Jennifer Harbury, pressured the White House to investigate CIA involvement in assassinations in Guatemala.
